title: Dad reveals why he's BANNED his six daughters from doing homework (even though they enjoy it)
text:

A dad has revealed why he has banned his six children from doing their homework - despite the fact they "absolutely love" it. 
Dr Justin Coulson, a leading parenting expert, writes an annual letter to his kids' teachers , explaining his view on the matter. 
He suggests that it is not only children who typically dislike the tradition (except his own), but also parents and teachers. 
He then goes on to cite "the growing body of evidence" that homework can actually have a negative effect on primary school children. Read More Secondary school may change its start time - because pupils can't get out of bed 
"As a result," Dr Coulson adds, "until my children’s school banned homework, I actually banned my children from doing homework before high school." 
He shares the letter, sent to his kids' school every year, on his blog . It appears his stance is sometimes met with disbelief, as he feels the need to tell the teacher: 
"As you will probably see, we have put a lot of effort into this letter, and we hope that you will take it seriously, and also recognise that we wish to make things better for all parties, and not more challenging." 
His reasons for not encouraging his children to do homework include that it may increase teachers' workload, it can create stress for kids, it creates an "extra burden" on parents and it can cause family conflict. 
He also claims that homework is "generally not inspiring" and it diminishes the time children have for other activities. Dr Coulson writes an annual letter to his kids' teachers (file picture) (Photo: Getty) 
And he says: "For young children (under around age 14-15 years) there is no scientific research which supports the inclusion of homework in their after-school activities." 
Speaking to Daily Mail Australia , Dr Coulson explains: "In instances where they were upset my response has been to inform them that I think it is the height of institutional arrogance to tell me how to raise my children at home." Read More Angry nursery staff lecture parents about pick-up time etiquette – with a powerful note 
Referring to his own brood of girls and their attitude to homework, he says, "'They absolutely love it and it drives me crazy... 
"But I make it clear that there are things that take precedence like going for a swim in the afternoon or having afternoon tea together and enjoying family time." Read More Does pushy parenting really work or are you simply raising trophy children? 
So instead of school-mandated homework, what does Dr Coulson want children to be doing in their spare time? How involved should parents be? 
His answer: reading and projects. These two "exceptions" to his stance on homework are specified in his letter. He says his children "absolutely love" doing homework (file picture) (Photo: Getty) 
On reading, Dr Coulson says that diving into a book every day is strongly encouraged in his house. However, page quotas or minimum time requirements are not set. 
Instead, he says: "When we simply remind the kids that reading time needs to happen, they immerse themselves in books and often only resurface after our pleas to come to the dinner table reach a crescendo!" 
It's clear that the child's enthusiasm for learning is paramount to Dr Coulson, who has written several books on parenting and has a doctorate in psychology. Read More Mum who banned her 13-year-old from using his mobile phone says ALL parents should do the same 
On projects, he says: "Our other form of “acceptable” homework is related to projects from school that interest the children." 
Along with high (but not too high) parental expectations , working with a child's interests and natural curiosity are Dr Coulson's keys to success for your school-age children. 
Despite his stance on homework, he does acknowledge on his blog that the activity can be beneficial in some situations. 
He writes: "I’ve seen some kids who were struggling at school. But with patient help from parents or tutors, their homework has helped them excel (or at least catch up.)." 
He adds: "Some kids just love doing homework. 
"I’m not about to suggest that they should stop." poll loading Do you think children should be given homework? 0+ VOTES SO FAR
